hints_html:
Use integration by parts.

Let \(f(x)=\ln x\) and \(g'(x)=x^2\).
hints_raw:
Use integration by parts.
Let <math>f(x)=\ln x</math> and <math>g'(x)=x^2</math>.
question: 1 (d)
sols_html:
Integrating by parts,

\[\begin{aligned} \int x^2\ln x\, dx &= \frac{x^3}{3} \ln x - \int \frac{x^3}{3}\frac{1}{x}\, dx\\ &= \frac{x^3}{3} \ln x - \int \frac{x^2}{3}\, dx\\ &= \frac{x^3}{3} \ln x - \frac{x^3}{9} +C. \end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
Integrating by parts,<br />
<math>\begin{align}
\int x^2\ln x\, dx &= \frac{x^3}{3} \ln x - \int  \frac{x^3}{3}\frac{1}{x}\, dx\\
&= \frac{x^3}{3} \ln x -  \int  \frac{x^2}{3}\, dx\\
&= \frac{x^3}{3} \ln x - \frac{x^3}{9} +C. \\
\end{align}</math>
